Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Algorithms for Computational Geometry Problems in Polygonal Domains

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tremendous progress has been made in the field of computational geometry in the last few decades. Efficient algorithms have been developed to solve geometric problems. However, there are many problems in computational geometry that do not yet have good algorithms or even do not have any algorithmic solutions. The main goal of this project is the development of new fundamental techniques in algorithms for solving those geometric problems.

This project aims to investigate a particular group of problems in computational geometry: problems in polygonal domains (or polygons with holes) in the plane. These problems are particularly interesting and fundamental because they model many geometric problems in the plane. The specific problems include computing shortest paths measured by Euclidean or other metrics, minimum link paths, other geometric paths, geodesic Voronoi diagrams, visibility polygons, geodesic diameter and center, polygon decomposition, facility locations, and geometric data structures, etc. The goal is to develop new algorithmic techniques for solving these problems efficiently. This research will bring diverse methodologies from other areas such as discrete mathematics, graph theory, operations research, combinatorial optimization, computational complexity, data structures, etc. The project is expected to greatly improve our understanding of the geometric structures of the problems in polygonal domains and to produce new algorithmic tools for solving these problems.

This research will potentially enrich the area of computational geometry by introducing new techniques. The algorithms and observations obtained from the project will also benefit computer science and other related disciplines where geometric algorithms are widely used. Another important part of this project is to train graduate students to practice in doing research, especially in developing algorithms for solving problems in computational geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studies a number of computational geometry problems in polygonal domains (or polygons with holes). Most of these are classical problems in computational geometry and have been studied before. The objective is to develop better algorithms and data structures than previously obtained. Fruitful results have been obtained from the project. Several major results include the following. 1) A new data structure for answering two-point shortest path queries in polygonal domains under L1 metric. The result has been published in a prestigious computational geometry conference (SoCG 2014) and also in a journal (Journal of Computational Geometry). 2) A new algorithm for computing minimum-link paths in rectilinear polygonal domains. The algorithm is actually optimal if the polygonal domain has been triangulated. The result has been published in a prestigious algorithm conference (ICALP 2015). 3) New algorithms for computing the geodesic diameter and geodesic center in polygonal domains under the L1 metric. The result has been published in a prestigious journal (Discrete & Computational Geometry). 4) A new algorithm for computing the geodesic center in polygonal domain under the Euclidean metric. The result has been published in a prestigious algorithm conference (ESA 2016). 5) A new algorithm for computing the visibility graph of a polygonal domain. The result has been published in a prestigious journal (Journal of Computational Geometry). 6) A new data structure for answering quickest visibility queries in polygonal domains. The result has been published in a prestigious computational geometry conference (SoCG 2017). 7) New algorithms for computing bicriteria rectilinear shortest paths in rectilinear polygonal domains. The result has been published in a prestigious computational geometry conference (SoCG 2017). In order to solve these problems, we also discovered many interesting observations on the geometric structures of polygonal domains and derived quite a few algorithmic techniques. These observations and algorithmic techniques may be useful for solving other related problems in polygonal domains.

The research results from this project have been widely disseminated to the research community and impacted the current active research on computational geometry, particularly on problems in polygonal domains. The research results have been published in prestigious journals and conferences, such as Discrete & Computational Geometry, Symposium on Computational Geometry (SoCG), etc. A course on computational geometry has been developed. Some research results have also been introduced to the students in class. Three graduate students, one Master and two Ph.D (one female), have been supported and trained by the project. The master student and a Ph.D student have already graduated. The other Ph.D student has been supported by the project for three years and obtained many good results. Under the support of the project, the graduate students have had chances to attend conferences and workshops to present their research and meet with senior researchers from other institutions. This benefits the research development of the students and eventually helps them make their future career decisions. As a result, the female Ph.D student who recently graduated joined a university and is now a tenure-track assistant professor there.
